head.title: Right to Pollute Will Cost Less

hedline.hl1: Right to Pollute Will Cost Less

block.p: It will cost electric utilities 48 percent less this year for the right to pollute than it did last year, based on the Environmental Protection Agency's fourth annual auction of pollution allowances at the Chicago Board of Trade.
The cost to emit a ton of sulfur dioxide into the atmosphere this year dropped to an average of $68.14 at this week's auction from $132 a year ago. Sulfur dioxide is a major cause of acid rain.

It will cost electric utilities 48 percent less this year for the right to pollute than it did last year, based on the Environmental Protection Agency's fourth annual auction of pollution allowances at the Chicago Board of Trade.
The cost to emit a ton of sulfur dioxide into the atmosphere this year dropped to an average of $68.14 at this week's auction from $132 a year ago. Sulfur dioxide is a major cause of acid rain.
Energy experts attribute the lower price to improvements in pollution control technology and the deregulation of railroads, which has reduced the cost of transporting low-sulfur coal.

The Clean Air Act of 1990 requires the E.P.A. to sponsor a one-day auction in which electric utilities bid for the right to pollute. The idea is to give utilities an economic incentive to pollute less.
The auction program rewards utilities that have reduced pollution by allowing them to sell unneeded allowances to private brokers or to other utilities.
The highest bid for 1996, or spot, rights was $300 for each allowance, while the lowest was $39. The minimum winning bid for the 150,000 spot allowances sold was $66.05.
